1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

We at SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC are committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of Ammonia (anhydrous).  In the event that an accidental release did occur, our highly trained employees are available to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  We are also completely coordinated with the Albuquerque Fire Department, who provides our on-site emergency response services.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:

We have one substance that is regulated by the Process Safety and Risk Management regulations at our facility.  That substance is Ammonia (anhydrous).  The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present at this facility, based on process and operational requirements is 15,200 pounds.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA's Clean Air Act.  Our Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system is also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following sections will briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Our facility conducts comprehensive analyses to ensure that all of the hazards associated with our Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system are identified and controlled safely.  The methodology used to conduct these analyses is the What-If Checklist.  The analyse

s are completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in the engineering, maintenance, operation and safety of the system and are updated at an interval of at least every 5 years.  Any corrective actions noted in these analyses are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  The information in these procedures is reviewed at least annually by personnel who operate and/or maintain the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system.

Training:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC has a comprehensive training program to ensure that personnel who operate and/or maintain the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system receive initial and refresher training and evaluations.  New personnel receive basic classroom training in the operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system, followed by on-the-job training and supervision until they are evaluated and competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at an interval of at least every three years.

Mechanical Integrity:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC completes preventive maintenance inspections and tests of the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system to ensure safe and proper operation.  The equipment examined during these inspections and tests includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  All personnel who inspect and/or test the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system are given initial and subsequent refresher training at a frequency of at least every three years.

Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC to manage changes in the Ammonia (anhydrous) r

efrigeration system chemicals, technology, equipment and processes.  A Process Safety Committee, consisting of personnel who design, install, maintain and operate the refrigeration system, review all changes that would or could affect the safety and/or mechanical integrity of the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system.

Pre-Startup Reviews:

Pre-Startup Reviews related to new processes, and to modifications of established processes, are conducted by the Process Safety Committee for all changes that would or could affect the safety and/or mechanical integrity of the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system.

Compliance Audits:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC conducts regulatory compliance audits on a regular basis to determine whether the requirements of both the Process Safety and Risk Management Planning regulations are being implemented.  These compliance audits are completed at a frequency of at least every three years.

Incident Investigation:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC investigates any accident that has resulted in, or incident that could reaqsonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  These investigations are conducted to identify the circumstances leading up to the accident or incident, as well as any corrective actions to prevent the accident or incident from recurring.  All accident/incident reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC believes that Process Safety and Risk Management compliance require a team effort.  Personnel who design, install, maintain or operate the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system are included in a Process Safety Committee to oversee the safety and mechanical integrity of the system.  Both employees and non-employees have access to all information releated to our Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system, including our process hazard analyses.

Contractors:

Occasionally, SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC

hires contractors to conduct specialized construction or maintenance activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance and competency is completed.  SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of the hazards related to the contractor's work at our facility.  Contractors are also trained in the procedures for emergency notification, evacuation and personnel accountability, should an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) occur.

4. 5-Year Accident History:

No reportable accidents or incidents have occurred at this facility during the past 5 years.

5. Emergency Response Plan:

SYSCO Food Services of New Mexico, LLC is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility also has it's own emergency response plan.  The emergency response plan includes specific actions to be taken in response to the accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  The emergency response plan includes procedures for informing the public and the local response agencies regarding a release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  The emergency response plan also includes information on emergency health care.

The date of the most recent review and/or update of our emergency response plan was June 20, 2005.

The date of the most recent emergency response plan training for our employees was June 16, 2005.

The local agency coordinating our emergency response plan is the Bernalillo County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Their telephone number is 505.855.6399  

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Several developments and changes have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our Process Safety and Risk Management Plans.  We will continue our annual facility emergency notification, evacuation and accountability training and drills.
